name: Ramsey numbers R(3,n).
comment: a(10) is either 40, 41, or 42 (Goedgebeur, Radziszowski). - _Ray G. Opao_, Oct 07 2015

Kim proves that a(n) ≍ n^2/log n; the lower and upper constants, respectively, can be chosen arbitrarily close to 1/162 and 1. (Kim notes that he made no attempt to make 1/162 tight.) - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jun 23 2023
As of 31 December 2023, Vigleik Angeltveit claims to have ruled out a(10)=42 with a massive computer search. See links. That would mean that 40 <= a(10) <= 41. - _Allan C. Wechsler_, Apr 05 2024
